doc.ContractDescription: THIS PROPOSAL SEEKS TO ENHANCE SCIENCE RETURN FROM THE CHEMCAM INSTRUMENT BY IMPROVING ITS CAPABILITY TO PROVIDE ACCURATE CHEMICAL ANALYSES OF MARTIAN SURFACE MATERIALS, RELATING ITS RESULTS TO THOSE OF THE MORE MATURE APXS INSTRUMENT AND ENHANCING OUR UNDERSTANDING OF GEOCHEMICAL PROCESSES THAT OCCUR ON THE SURFACE OF MARS. TO DEAL WITH CHEMICAL MATRIX EFFECTS THAT CAUSE INTERACTIONS IN THE LIBS PLASMA, WE WILL USE MULTIVARIATE STATISTICAL METHODS TO IMPROVE THE ACCURACY OF QUANTITATIVE ELEMENTAL ANALYSES. THESE WILL FACILITATE EFFECTIVE USE OF GEOCHEMICAL CLASSIFICATIONS SO THAT RESULTS CAN BE USE TO INFORM OUR UNDERSTANDING OF BOTH MAGMATIC EVOLUTION ON MARS AND SUBSEQUENT ALTERATION PROCESSES. TO THIS END, WE WILL UNDERTAKE FOUR SEPARATE SCIENCE TASKS, ALL DIRECTLY RELATED TO SOLICITED INVESTIGATIONS IN THE ANNOUNCEMENT OF OPPORTUNITY. 1) WE PLAN TO BROADEN THE REPRESENTATION OF COMPOSITIONS AND INCREASE THE SIZE OF THE CHEMCAM CALIBRATION SUITE BY AN ORDER OF MAGNITUDE USING WELL-CHARACTERIZED MARS-ANALOG SAMPLES; STATISTICAL METHODS WILL IDENTIFY GAPS IN COMPOSITION SPACE WHERE STANDARDS ARE LACKING, AND THE P.I. WILL FIND OR CREATE SAMPLES TO FILL THOSE GAPS. WE WILL ALSO UNDERTAKE TO PROVIDE AND STUDY CROSS-PLATFORM STANDARDS FOR MUCH-NEEDED COMPARISONS BETWEEN LASER-INDUCED BREAKDOWN SPECTROSCOPY (LIBS) AND APXS DATA. 2) WE WILL USE MULTIVARIATE STATISTICS TO DEVELOP AUTOMATED PROCEDURES TO CHOOSE AN OPTIMAL COMBINATION OF PREDICTIVE SAMPLES FOR EACH ELEMENT FROM AMONG THOSE IN THAT CALIBRATION SUITE, PRODUCING GEOCHEMICAL ANALYSES WITH THE LOWEST POSSIBLE ERRORS. 3) WE WILL IMPROVE UPON OUR EXISTING END-TO-END MODELS THAT SIMULATE SIGNAL DEGRADATION RESULTING FROM MISALIGNMENT OR DECREASES IN SIGNAL AMPLITUDE AND EVALUATE THEIR EFFECTS ON MULTIVARIATE MODEL PREDICTIONS; THESE INSIGHTS CAN THEN BE USED TO EXTRACT MEANINGFUL RESULTS FROM LIBS DATA EVEN IN LOW SIGNAL-TO-NOISE CONDITIONS. 4) WE WILL STAFF OUR LIBS LAB AND PROVIDE SAMPLES FOR USE IN VALIDATION DURING THE MISSION. THIS WORK WILL ALLOW CHEMCAM TO BETTER ADDRESS TWO SPECIFIC SCIENCE OBJECTIVES OF MARS SCIENCE LABORATORY BY FOCUSING ON DETERMINATION OF CHEMICAL COMPOSITION, AND ALLOWING BETTER CHARACTERIZATION OF AQUEOUS PROCESSES ON MARS. BY CONTRIBUTING TO IMPROVEMENTS IN THE ACCURACY OF CHEMCAM RESULTS AND AN UNDERSTANDING OF HOW ITS RESULTS RELATE TO THOSE OF THE APXS, WE WILL HELP PROVIDE THE BEST POSSIBLE GEOCHEMICAL DATA FOR INTEGRATION WITH RESULTS FROM OTHER MSL INSTRUMENTATION, PARTICULARLY CHEMIN.

doc.ContractDescription: OVER THE LAST TWO DECADES, GROWING GLOBAL DEMAND FOR BEEF AND COMMODITY CROPS HAS INCREASED PRESSURE ON BRAZIL S NATIVE ECOSYSTEMS, PARTICULARLY THE FORESTS (AMAZON) AND SAVANNAS (CERRADO) THAT STRADDLE THE AGRICULTURAL FRONTIER. MEANWHILE, MOUNTING PRESSURE TO REDUCE AMAZON DEFORESTATION AND INCREASE AGRICULTURAL PRODUCTION HAS BROUGHT ABOUT A NEW PARADIGM OF CATTLE EXPANSION. THE NEW MODEL FOCUSES ON INCREASING PRODUCTION IN NON-FOREST REGIONS (E.G. THE CERRADO), PARTICULARLY IN ALREADY CLEARED PASTURELANDS THAT CAN ACCOMMODATE EXPANSION AND INTENSIFICATION WHILE AVOIDING FURTHER CLEARING. THESE SHIFTING INCENTIVES HAVE TRIGGERED RAPID LAND-USE CHANGES IN BRAZIL S AGRICULTURAL FRONTIER AND DRAMATIC SHIFTS IN THE ASSOCIATED GREENHOUSE GAS (GHG) EMISSIONS SINCE THE TURN OF THE CENTURY. TODAY CATTLE RANCHING IS THE SINGLE LARGEST SOURCE OF GHG EMISSIONS IN BRAZIL, BUT EXISTING ESTIMATES ARE ROUGH. DESPITE RESEARCH EFFORTS TO QUANTIFY GHG EMISSIONS FROM CATTLE RANCHING, SEVERAL IMPORTANT KNOWLEDGE GAPS REMAIN. FIRST, THERE IS A LACK OF SPATIALLY CONSISTENT ANNUAL DATA ON PASTURE EXTENT, PARTICULARLY IN THE BRAZILIAN CERRADO. SECOND, MOST ESTIMATES OF GHG EMISSIONS FROM RANCHING IGNORE A POTENTIALLY LARGE SOURCE OF GHGS THE HUNDREDS OF THOUSANDS OF SMALL RESERVOIRS SCATTERED ACROSS BRAZIL S RANGELANDS TO PROVIDE DRINKING WATER FOR CATTLE. THIRD, WE KNOW LITTLE ABOUT HOW PASTURE DYNAMICS ARE CHANGING IN THE LANDSCAPE AND HOW THAT INTERACTS WITH RESERVOIR ABUNDANCE. THE PROPOSED PROJECT WILL ADDRESS THESE GAPS USING A COMBINATION OF FIELD MEASUREMENTS, REMOTE SENSING, AND MODELING TO ANSWER THE FOLLOWING KEY QUESTIONS: (1) HOW HAVE RECENT LAND-USE TRANSITIONS AFFECTED THE DISTRIBUTION AND INTENSIFICATION OF CATTLE PRODUCTION IN BRAZIL S AGRICULTURAL FRONTIER? (2) WHAT ARE THE INDIVIDUAL AND CUMULATIVE CONTRIBUTIONS OF AGRICULTURAL RESERVOIRS TO BRAZIL S CARBON BUDGET? (3) WHAT ARE THE CURRENT AND POTENTIAL FUTURE CUMULATIVE GHG EMISSIONS ASSOCIATED WITH CATTLE RANCHING IN BRAZIL? THE PROJECT WILL SUPPORT THE FIRST ROBUST FIELD-BASED ESTIMATE OF GREENHOUSE GAS (CH4 AND CO2) EMISSIONS FROM SMALL TROPICAL RESERVOIRS (<1 KM2), AS WELL AS DEVELOPMENT OF NEW REMOTE SENSING APPROACHES TO ENABLE MAPPING OF RESERVOIRS AND PASTURES OVER LARGE AREAS. THESE RESULTS WILL PROVIDE THE BASIS FOR MORE REALISTIC ESTIMATES OF CUMULATIVE EMISSIONS FROM CATTLE RANCHING IN BRAZIL. THE METHODS DEVELOPED WILL FACILITATE OPERATIONAL MONITORING AND LARGE-SCALE LAND USE PLANNING. THE PROJECT WILL THUS MAKE AN IMPORTANT CONTRIBUTION TOWARDS MEASURING THE CLIMATE IMPACTS OF LAND USE POLICIES; EVALUATING THE TRADEOFFS BETWEEN AMAZON AND CERRADO DEVELOPMENT; AND CREATING NEW INCENTIVES TO PROTECT NATIVE CERRADO ECOSYSTEMS. BRAZIL AND OTHER TROPICAL NATIONS ARE THE LAST REMAINING AGRICULTURAL FRONTIER AND THE PLACES WHERE SOCIETY MUST NEGOTIATE A DELICATE BALANCE BETWEEN FOOD SECURITY, ECOSYSTEM CONSERVATION, AND CLIMATE STABILITY. THE IMPROVED UNDERSTANDING OF PASTURE EXTENT AND ASSOCIATED GHG EMISSIONS RESULTING FROM THIS PROJECT WILL ALLOW US TO EXPLORE THESE TRADEOFFS THROUGH A SERIES OF FUTURE LAND USE SCENARIOS. ULTIMATELY, THE PROJECT WILL SHED LIGHT ON THE VULNERABILITY OF FORESTS AND SAVANNAS IN BRAZIL TO DIFFERENT ECONOMIC DEVELOPMENT PATHWAYS. THESE RESULTS ARE APPLICABLE TO OTHER TROPICAL DRY FORESTS AND SAVANNAS (E.G. THE MIOMBO WOODLANDS OF AFRICA) AND MAY HELP IDENTIFY SENSOR CHARACTERISTICS THAT COULD (IN FUTURE MISSIONS) IMPROVE CHARACTERIZATION OF THESE IMPORTANT ECOSYSTEMS.

doc.ContractDescription: IGF::OT::IGF BOSTON HARBOR&PORTSMOUTH HARBOR FISHERIES SURVEY - BOSTON, MA AND PORTSMOUTH, MA

WE PROPOSE TO CONDUCT A STUDY TO IMPROVE OUR UNDERSTANDING OF HEAT AND FRESH WATER EXCHANGE IN THE SPURS-2 REGION THROUGH DIRECT ESTIMATES OF THE HEAT, MOISTURE, AND MOMENTUM FLUXES, THEIR RELATED MEAN VARIABLES, AND PRECIPITATION. THE SALINITY VARIABILITY OF THE UPPER OCEAN IS PROFOUNDLY INFLUENCED BY THE FRESHWATER FLUX AT THE SURFACE, IN COMBINATION WITH THE EFFECTS OF MIXING AND ADVECTION WITHIN THE UPPER OCEAN. THE MIXING IN THE UPPER OCEAN IS ITSELF AFFECTED BY THE SURFACE FLUXES OF FRESHWATER, MOMENTUM, AND HEAT. THUS, IN ORDER TO UNDERSTAND THE LINKAGES BETWEEN THE PRECIPITATION EVENTS THAT OCCUR AT CLOUD SCALES THROUGH TO THE UPPER OCEAN SALINITY BALANCE AND THEN TO THE LARGER TIME- AND SPACE-SCALES, IT IS NECESSARY TO ACCURATELY MEASURE THESE FLUXES. A PRIMARY GOAL OF THIS RESEARCH IS TO PROVIDE MEASUREMENTS FROM SHIP DEPLOYMENTS DURING THE SPURS-2 EXPERIMENT IN THE TROPICAL EASTERN PACIFIC OCEAN THAT CAN BE USED IN CONJUNCTION WITH OTHER ON-BOARD MEASUREMENTS SUCH AS SURFACE AND PROFILE TEMPERATURE, SALINITY, CURRENT, AND OCEAN MIXING OBSERVATIONS IN ORDER TO PROVIDE A FULL PICTURE OF THE LINKAGES BETWEEN THE SURFACE FORCING AND THE RESULTING UPPER OCEAN STRUCTURE. THIS WILL BE ACCOMPLISHED THROUGH THE USE OF INSTRUMENTS TO MEASURE THE TURBULENT FLUXES OF HEAT, MOISTURE, AND MOMENTUM, IN ADDITION TO PRECIPITATION AND RADIATION FLUXES. THE PRINCIPLE HYPOTHESIS OF THIS RESEARCH IS THAT THE SURFACE FLUXES ARE A KEY FACTOR IN THE EVOLUTION OF SALINITY VARIABILITY IN THIS REGION, AND THAT MEASUREMENTS OF THESE PARAMETERS WILL GREATLY ENHANCE OUR ABILITY TO SIMULATE AND PREDICT THE UPPER OCEAN SALINITY BUDGET AND RESULTING SALINITY STRUCTURE IN THIS REGION.
IGF::OT::IGF PREVENTATIVE MAINTENANCE FOR COOK CHILL SYSTEM

doc.ContractDescription: AGRICULTURAL COMMODITIES PURCHASED FOR DOMESTIC FOOD DISTRIBUTION PROGRAMS. VEGETABLE OIL PRODUCTS WBSCM PO: 4100010196

OUR OVERARCHING GOAL IS TO DEVELOP ROBUST ALGORITHMS TO RETRIEVE WATER QUALITY PROPERTIES FROM SATELLITE OCEAN COLOR DATA MEASURED OVER OPTICALLY SHALLOW WATERS OSWS, SINCE CURRENT OCEAN COLOR PROCESSING ALGORITHMS ARE UNABLE TO REMOVE THE BOTTOM EFFECTS IN SUCH IMPORTANT AQUATIC ENVIRONMENTS. THIS PROJECT WILL USE BOTH SIMULATED AND IN SITU DATA TO DETERMINE THE OPTIMAL ALGORITHM ARCHITECTURE AND ALGORITHM PARAMETERIZATION FOR THIS GOAL. IN PARTICULAR, BECAUSE OF THE RICHNESS IN HABITATS AND THE ECOLOGICAL AND ECONOMIC IMPORTANCE, WE WILL USE THE SHALLOW WATERS IN THE FLORIDA REGION THE WEST FLORIDA SHELF, TAMPA BAY, SOUTH FLORIDA, FLORIDA KEYS, AND BAHAMAS AS A TEST BED FOR THE GENERATION AND EVALUATION OF WATER QUALITY PROPERTIES IN SHALLOW WATERS FROM SATELLITE OCEAN COLOR DATA. THE SIGNIFICANT OUTCOMES OF THIS EFFORT WILL INCLUDE ROBUST ALGORITHMS DOCUMENTATION, AUXILIARY DATASET, AND SEADAS COMPATIBLE SOFTWARE FOR PROCESSING SATELLITE OCEAN COLOR DATA OVER OSWS, WHICH WILL FILL THE VOID IN GENERATING RELIABLE WATER QUALITY PRODUCTS FOR SUCH ENVIRONMENTS. IN ADDITION, THE PROJECT WILL ESTABLISH AN EFFECTIVE DATABASE MAPS OF BOTTOM PROPERTIES DEPTH, REFLECTANCE, AND BOTTOM TYPE FOR OSWS IN THE FLORIDA REGION. IN COMBINATION WITH EXISTING ALGORITHMS DEVELOPED AND VALIDATED FOR OPTICALLY DEEP WATERS, THE ALGORITHM SUITE WITH APPROPRIATE AUXILIARY DATASET WILL BE ABLE TO PROVIDE SEAMLESS WATER QUALITY PRODUCTS FROM DEEP TO SHALLOW WATERS, WHICH WILL HAVE A BROAD IMPACT ON THE MONITORING AND STUDY OF DELICATE CORAL REEF AND SEA GRASS ECOSYSTEMS BEYOND OUR STUDY REGION. FURTHERMORE, THE ALGORITHM SUITE WILL BE APPLIED TO MORE THAN A DECADE OF SATELLITE SEAWIFS, MODIS MEASUREMENTS TO DOCUMENT AND EVALUATE DECADAL CHANGES OF WATER QUALITY IN THE FLORIDA REGION, AND TO STUDY THEIR POTENTIAL LINKS WITH CLIMATE VARIABILITY AND HUMAN IMPACTS. RESULTS OF THESE CASE STUDIES WILL BE USED TO SUPPORT MANAGEMENT DECISION MAKING, FOR EXAMPLE BY PROVIDING BASELINE DATA TO THE CURRENT RE ZONING EFFORT OF THE FLORIDA KEYS NATIONAL MARINE SANCTUARY. THIS PROPOSAL IS A DIRECT RESPONSE TO NASA ROSES 2012 NNH11ZDA001N A.32 SUB ELEMENT 2.2.2 SHALLOW WATER. THE RESULTS WILL HELP ADDRESS SCIENCE ISSUES RELATED TO NASA SCIENCE MISSION DIRECTORATE STRATEGIC GOAL IA. STUDY PLANET EARTH FROM SPACE TO ADVANCE SCIENTIFIC UNDERSTANDING AND MEET SOCIETAL NEEDS. THE PROJECT WILL BENEFIT SIGNIFICANTLY FROM THE EXTENSIVE EXPERIENCE AND EXPERTISE OF THE TEAM MEMBERS WORKING ON THIS TOPIC, AND FROM THE EXISTING DATA PROCESSING INFRASTRUCTURE ESTABLISHED FROM PAST AND CURRENT NASA PROJECTS.

WE ARE INVESTING A NUMBER OF ASPECTS OF PHASE SEPARATION IN ATTRACTIVE COLLOID-POLYMER MIXTURES, LOOKING AT SPINODAL DECOMPOSITION NEAR THE BINODAL LINE, AS WE APPROACH THE CRITICAL POINT. THESE EQUILIBRIUM PHASE-SEPARATION PROCESSES ARE DIFFICULT TO STUDY ON EARTH, AS THE TWO PHASES ARE ALMOST ALWAYS OF DIFFERENT DENSITIES. THE STABLE MICROGRAVITY ENVIRONMENT OF THE INTERNATIONAL SPACE STATION THEREFORE PROVIDES UNIQUE OPPORTUNITIES TO INVESTIGATE THESE PARTICULAR PROCESSES, PARTICULARLY AS THESE PROCESSES LEAD TO THE CREATION OF CENTIMETER-SCALE STRUCTURES THAT ARE TOO FRAGILE TO MAINTAIN THEIR SHAPE IN THE NORMAL ENVIRONMENT OF EARTH'S GRAVITY. WE ARE EXTENDING A SERIES OF BCAT EXPERIMENTS, A DECADE-LONG EFFORT TO PHOTOGRAPH PHASE SEPARATION; BASED ON PREVIOUS RESULTS, WE ARE EXTENDING THE SCIENCE WITH NEW COLLOIDAL MATERIALS AND IMAGING AND ANALYSIS TECHNIQUES, TO LOOK AT HOW PHASE SEPARATION MAY INFLUENCE OTHER PROCESSES, SUCH AS GELATION AND CRYSTALLIZATION, ON THESE LENGTH- AND TIME-SCALES THAT CANNOT BE ACCESSED EASILY ON EARTH. WE WILL COMPLEMENT THESE MACROSCOPIC OBSERVATIONS WITH HIGH RESOLUTION FLUORESCENCE MICROSCOPY---WHERE SINGLE COLLOIDAL PARTICLES MAY BE VISIBLE. WE CAN THEN LOOK AT THE EARLY EVOLUTION OF THESE MIXTURES FOR THE FIRST SECONDS AND MINUTES, WITH ACCESS TO EXACT STRUCTURAL INFORMATION. BY COMBINING THESE TWO APPROACHES, PHOTOGRAPHY AND MICROSCOPY, WE WILL BE ABLE TO LOOK AT STRUCTURE AND DYNAMICS THROUGH SEVERAL ORDERS OF MAGNITUDE IN SPACE AND TIME.

doc.ContractDescription: THIS PROPOSED STUDY WILL INVESTIGATE THE OCCURRENCE OF MID INFRARED EXCESSES FOUND IN WISE DATA IN LOW MASS FIELD STARS. THESE MIR EXCESSES ARE INTERPRETED AS DUST REPROCESSED STAR LIGHT, OCCURRING WHEN TERRESTRIAL PLANETARY BODIES COLLIDE. THESE SYSTEMS SERVE AS AN IMPORTANT SIGNATURES OF TERRESTRIAL PLANET FORMATION AND EVOLUTION. THIS PROPOSAL BUILDS OFF THE RESULTS OF A PILOT STUDY CONDUCTED USING WISE, 2MASS, AND SDSS OBSERVATIONS. THIS STUDY USED MIR OBSERVATIONS FROM WISE TO IDENTIFY 175 SPECTROSCOPICALLY CONFIRMED LOW MASS STARS EXHIBITING EXCESS MIR FLUX OVER EXPECTED STELLAR PHOTOSPHERIC LEVELS. THEISSEN&WEST INVESTIGATED OTHER EXPLANATIONS FOR STARS EXHIBITING EXCESS MIR FLUX. ACCOUNTING FOR ANY POSSIBLE CONTAMINANTS, 175 STARS WERE FOUND WITH MIR EXCESSES, AND A LOW PROBABILITY OF MIR EXCESSES BEING ATTRIBUTABLE TO A CONTAMINATING SOURCE. THROUGH INVESTIGATION OF THE DISK LUMINOSITIES AND APPROXIMATE STELLAR AGES ESTIMATED FROM SPECTROSCOPIC TRACERS, IT WAS DETERMINED THE MOST LIKELY CAUSE OF THE EXCESS MIR FLUX IS A LARGE ABUNDANCE OF CIRCUMSTELLAR MATERIAL, LIKELY CAUSED BY COLLISIONS BETWEEN PLANETARY BODIES. THE PILOT STUDY WAS LIMITED BY ITS SMALL SAMPLE SIZE AND INCOMPLETENESS DUE TO THE SDSS SPECTROSCOPIC TARGET SELECTION. OUR PROPOSED STUDY WILL USE A PHOTOMETRICALLY SELECTED SAMPLE TO CREATE A MORE COMPLETE AND STATISTICALLY SIGNIFICANT SAMPLE OF LOW MASS STARS EXHIBITING MIR EXCESSES. THE FIRST OBJECTIVE OF THIS PROPOSAL WILL BE TO CONSTRUCT A PHOTOMETRIC CATALOG OF LOW MASS STARS, COMBINING WISE, 2MASS, AND SDSS PHOTOMETRY. TO DIFFERENTIATE STARS FROM OTHER POINT-LIKE SOURCES OF SIMILAR COLOR, WE WILL USE PROPER MOTIONS. THE LARGE TIME BASELINES BETWEEN WISE, 2MASS, AND SDSS OBSERVATIONS ALLOW US TO COMPUTE RELIABLE PROPER MOTIONS FOR MILLIONS OF PHOTOMETRIC LOW MASS STARS CONTAINED WITHIN THE COMBINED DATASET. THE SECOND OBJECTIVE OF THIS PROPOSAL WILL BE TO SELECT STARS WITH APPARENT INFRARED EXCESSES, AND REMOVE SOURCES WITH ANY POSSIBLE CONTAMINANTS USING THE METHODS FROM THEISSEN&WEST, WHICH ARE EASILY SCALABLE TO MILLIONS OF SOURCES. THEISSEN&WEST USED TWO METHODS TO DETERMINE STARS WITH EXCESS MIR FLUX. THE FIRST METHOD IS COMPLETELY EMPIRICAL, USING VISIBLE AND INFRARED COLORS TO DIFFERENTIATE STARS WITH MIR EXCESSES FROM TYPICAL MAIN SEQUENCE COLORS. THIS METHOD CAN EASILY BE SCALED TO THE MILLIONS OF STARS EXPECTED IN THE PROPER MOTION CATALOG ABOVE. THIS PHOTOMETRIC SAMPLE WILL ALSO ALLOW US TO BETTER CONSTRAIN LOW-MASS STAR MAIN SEQUENCE COLORS DUE TO THE ORDERS OF MAGNITUDE LARGER NUMBER OF STARS CONTAINED WITHIN. THE SECOND METHOD IS TO FIT MODEL STELLAR SPECTRAL ENERGY DISTRIBUTIONS TO VISIBLE AND NEAR-INFRARED DATA IN ORDER TO CONSTRAIN THE STELLAR PARAMETERS. THIS WILL BE DONE USING A MONTE CARLO MARKOV CHAIN TO EXPLORE THE STELLAR PARAMETER SPACE AND CONSTRAIN A BEST FIT MODEL, WHILE ALSO PROVIDING AN UNCERTAINTY ESTIMATE ON EACH PARAMETER. A NUMBER OF MCMC FRAMEWORKS ARE AVAILABLE FOR US TO USE, AND WITH THE BOSTON UNIVERSITY SHARED COMPUTING CLUSTER, THIS METHOD IS ALSO SCALABLE TO MILLIONS OF SOURCES. THESE MODELS WILL ALLOW US TO ESTIMATE AN EXPECTED MIR FLUX, AND COMPARE THAT TO THE OBSERVED WISE MIR FLUX. LASTLY, USING A GALACTIC MODEL TO REPRODUCE EXPECTED STELLAR DENSITIES AND KINEMATICS, WE WILL DETERMINE THE EXPECTED NUMBER OF STARS PER LOCATION AND PROPER MOTION BIN. WE CAN COMPARE THIS MODEL TO OUR OBSERVED NUMBER COUNTS TO STUDY THE FREQUENCY OF LOW MASS FIELD STARS EXHIBITING IR EXCESSES, AND CONSTRAIN THE OCCURRENCE OF COLLISIONS IN PLANETARY SYSTEMS.
